title: Concave mirror - f from lamp and card distances

content.question: A group of students wishes to experimentally determine the focal length <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math> of a concave (converging) mirror. The students have a lamp and use the mirror to form a focused image of the lamp on a white card. With the lamp located at different positions, the students measure the distance <math alttext="d sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></math> between the lamp and the mirror as well as the distance <math alttext="d sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mi>C</mi></msub></math> between the card and the mirror when the image is in focus on the card. Are these measurements sufficient to determine <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math>? What reasoning helps support the claim?

choices.label: No. The image and object heights must also be measured so that the magnification can be determined.
No. The mirrorâ€™s radius of curvature must also be measured before <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math> can be determined.

Yes. Using a best-fit line to a graph of <math alttext="the fraction 1 over d sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msub><mi>d</mi><mi>C</mi></msub></mfrac></math> as a function of <math alttext="the fraction 1 over d sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msub><mi>d</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></mfrac></math>, <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math> can be calculated from the slope of the line.

Yes. Using a best-fit line to a graph of <math alttext="the fraction 1 over d sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msub><mi>d</mi><mi>C</mi></msub></mfrac></math> as a function of <math alttext="the fraction 1 over d sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msub><mi>d</mi><mi>L</mi></msub></mfrac></math>, <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math> can be calculated from either the vertical-axis intercept or the horizontal-axis intercept of the line.
